716573f-a.title: Manhattan: Battery Place - West Street
716573f-a.text:
Battery Place, east from West to State Streets and showing buildings
on the north side of same which at this date contained numerous rookeries,
the result of their proximity to Castle Garden; the immigrant landing
depot. The latter is in Battery Park; which appears partially on the
right. Prominent edifices are (from left to right) the Standard Oil
Building;;the Wielles Building; the Washington Building: The United States
Custom House (flag atop) and the Battery Park Building. Note at Greenwich
Streee the elevated station of the first elevated line in New York; this
today (1937) is used as a portion of the Sixth and Ninth Ave. lines.
About 1889.
Brown Brothers.
716573f-a.folder: Battery Place & West Street, Manhattan, NY

724545f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Battery Place
724545f-a.folder: West Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY

716571f-a.title: Manhattan: Battery Place - West Street
716571f-a.text:
Battery Place, north side, east from West Street, to Broadway, as seen
from across Battery Park. On the left, appears the Whitehall Building.
February 29, 1928.
New York Edison Co.
716571f-a.folder: Battery Place & West Street, Manhattan, NY

724538f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Battery Place
724538f-a.text:
West Street, east side, north from Battery Park (South Ferry). Also
shown is Battery Place, north side, east from and including West, to Wash-
ington Streets. Prominently shown, is the Whitehall Building (Nos. 1-14
West Street): said building consisting of 2 units, 20 and 32 stories in
height.
February 29, 1928.
New York Edison Company
724538f-a.folder: West Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY

730322f-b.title: General view - [Manhattan - Battery Place - West Street - Whitehall Building.]
730322f-b.text:
A general view northward (in No. 1) and eastward (No's 2 and 3)
from the Whitehall Building at Battery Place and West Street, to
ahow (in the first instance) the roof tops of the Syrian uarter and
the office structures surrounding same. The latter are grouped
around Bowling Green with the pyramidal Standard Oil Building doubly
depicted. Beyond is the East River and the Borough of Brooklyn. In
the background of No. 1 are the Telephone Company Building on West
Street and the Woolworth and Singer Buildings on Broadway.
June 20, 1929
Views 1,2 and 3
P. L. Sperr
730322f-b.folder: Battery Place - West Street - Whitehall Building., Manhattan, NY

July 3, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

724539f-b.title: Manhattan: West Street - Battery Place
724539f-b.text:
West Street, north rom Battery Place, showing an inclasive
view of this n arginal throughfare with buildings lining the
easterly side of same and facing North (Sudson)River piers.
To the risht in View No. 1 are the VUnitehall, the Downtown
Athletic Glub and the United Fruit Buildings. The promiuent
oenter structuro is the 29 story N. Y. Telephone Building.
View No. 2 shows only the pier fronts ano tne cars parked outside
of same.
Gctober 18, 1939

. 8perr

724543f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Battery Place
724543f-a.text:
CAPTIN POR PICTURID
A novel example of the set-back design of one building
helping its neighbor---the tall downtown athletic
club in the center and the thirty one story office
bullding known as 21 West St. at the right, showing
how the office structure was enabled to enjoy
southern exposure on both the Washington st. and West
St. sides of the site by virtue of the adjoining club
building being set back from its bullding line at
the street level. 'hus the Effice Bullding enj qys the
unicue positi n of an isolated structure with ite
Nashington, Morris a d West St. FrontaIes affording
it light from all foaar directions. The Building at the
left is the Whitehall Building at Batuery Place.
No date.
724543f-a.folder: West Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY
